title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" allows for grants to states to implement quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting children under the Social Security Act. The purpose of this section is to improve children's well-being through quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting children. States must submit a grant application describing these programs to receive funding. The grant supports high-quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting children. It includes outcomes and evidence of program effectiveness. A statewide needs assessment is required to determine program quality and capacity, as well as the number and types of eligible families. The curr_chunk discusses the number and types of eligible families receiving services, funding sources, gaps in home visitation services, and training activities in the State. Assurances from the State are also required for the programs. The curr_chunk outlines assurances required from the State to support home visitation programs, prioritizing communities in high need, especially those with low-income families or child maltreatment. The State must reserve 5 percent of grant funds for training and technical assistance for home visitation programs. Coordination with other child and family services, health services, and income supports is promoted. Referrals should be provided when appropriate. The State must reserve 5 percent of grant funds for training and technical assistance for home visitation programs. Home visitation programs supported using these funds should provide referrals to other programs serving children and families when appropriate. The State will comply with specified requirements and cooperate with evaluations. Other information as required by the Secretary will also be provided. The Secretary may require allotments to Indian tribes based on the number of children in the tribe whose families have income below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary shall allot funds to States based on the number of children in families with income below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary shall allot funds to States based on the number of children in families with income below 200 percent of the poverty line, with reallotments available for unspent funds. The State can reallot funds based on the allotment methodology specified. Funds reallotted are considered part of the State's allotment. States must maintain expenditures for home visitation programs for families with young children. Payment of grants is specified. The Secretary will make a grant to each State meeting requirements for eligible expenditures, based on a reimbursable percentage or allotted amount. The reimbursable percentage for eligible expenditures varies by fiscal year: 85% for 2010, 80% for 2011, and 75% for 2012 onwards. The term 'eligible expenditures' in this section refers to funds used for voluntary home visitation programs for families with young children, following evidence-based models with positive effects. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of home visitation programs that have positive effects on child and parenting outcomes. It emphasizes the need for well-trained staff, high-quality supervision, organizational capacity, and linkages to community resources. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need for home visitation programs to have well-trained staff, high-quality supervision, organizational capacity, and linkages to community resources. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence. The curr_chunk states that expenditures for programs not following a home visitation model with strong evidence of effectiveness may not be eligible if they exceed a certain percentage of the State's allotment for the fiscal year. The applicable percentage for fiscal years 2010 to 2014 is defined in subparagraph (A), and states that a State receiving a grant under this section cannot use other Federal funds to meet the State share of eligible expenditures. The Secretary may waive or modify provisions of this section for Indian tribes if it would impose an undue burden. An Indian tribe can meet certain requirements if the Secretary waives them. The Secretary can waive or modify requirements for Indian tribes under subsection (d) for subsections (c) and (e). States receiving grants must submit annual reports on program progress. The grant recipients must report on the services, program characteristics, provider qualifications, and recipient demographics. The program requires grant recipients to report on the number of recipients, demographic characteristics, family retention, annual cost, outcomes, training provided, and monitoring methods. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, and development. The evaluation will be conducted independently to determine program effectiveness. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, and development, as well as school readiness and links to community services. The effectiveness of these programs on different populations will also be examined to determine variations in outcomes across programs and populations. Within 2 years of enactment, an interim report will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary will submit an interim report to Congress within 2 years and a final report within 4 years on the evaluation of home visitation programs. Additionally, annual reports on program activities will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary will submit annual reports to Congress on activities funded under this section, including details on targeted communities, service delivery models, and program characteristics such as staff qualifications and demographics. The annual reports to Congress will include details on program staff qualifications, recipient characteristics, outcomes, research-based activities, and training activities funded under the grant. The annual reports to Congress will include details on program staff qualifications, recipient characteristics, outcomes, research-based activities, training, technical activities, costs of implementing programs, indicators used for monitoring, and reservations of funds for evaluation. The Secretary reserves funds for evaluation, training, and technical assistance in early childhood home visitation, as well as grants to Indian tribes. Appropriations are allocated to the Secretary for grants to Indian tribes under this section, with specific amounts designated for fiscal years 2010 to 2014. Indian tribes are treated as states in this context.
